REPC- f OF THE 4 TE OF NEBRASKA, TREASURY DEPARTMENT./ Lincoln, D mber 1, 1908. ( To His Excellency, George L, Sheldon, Governor of Nebraska. tSir: Pursuant to the requirements of law I have the honor to with present the following report of this department for the bien - i ending November 30, 1908, a!s:3 recommendations as contem - (d in article j, section 22, of tha constitution. I In making this report I call ycur attention to the -ipid reduction he state debt, which on Dec- iiber I, 190C was $1,^16,671.31 and ch on December 1, 190? according to the rc-'stered warrants in . Bee, is $71 8.57k. 33, b.uKing a net reduction during the two years |1, 198, 100. 98. In comparing the reduction as r. .'e from Decem - 1, 1907 to July 24, 1908 I would say that the state debt will be rely paid off by July 24, 1909, and I believe that the one mill levy le for the redemption of the state indebtedness will have answered purpose and it will not be necessary to make this one mill levy tl would also call your attention to interest returned upon state sits in the amount of $25,971.49, this being $9,271.19 greater i the amount of interest returned for the preceding biennium. is attributed to the i-Uerest being increase*, from two to three cent for the average daily balance of state funds deposited in the jus depository banks. STATE SCHOOL FINDS I By the passage of senate file No. 348 of the last legisuature pro - ing for the payment of warrants by the state treasurer and the estment of same in the school fund when sufficient money is on id 'a such fund, thereby t king these warrants from the hands of culators who desire to carry them as an investment, the records of i office are placed in such shape that our book shows . .s total amount state indebtedness by the daily balance of such registered warrants [ no general fund warrants have been registered for the holder same since April 5, 1907, so that the school fund has the benefit the interest accrued on all warants owed by the general fund of state. The money received from investments in warrants, from bonds coming due and from payment of principal on school land has to be reinvested by the Board of Educational Lands and Funds and the records of this department f r the past four years 'ndieate an average yearly investment of over $1,000,000. I believe the various county and school district bonds which will be offered for sale will be inade - quate to consume this sum of money available for investment, and this will require the buying of other state securities, as has been done in the pa«t. The records of this department show a larger, income received by reason of buying these bonds direct from the state which issue

STATE TREASURER 5 Ii and they also show an increase of one-half of one per cent for s purchased this biennium over the income received on bonds hased for the preceding bienninm, making an additional annual ne of $10,931 on the amount of I ?nds purchased during the past years. In o^der to maintain this precedent which has been es - shed, of go.ag out and buying bonds direct, I would recommend an appropriation be made available to this board for the continu - i of buying bonds direct from the various states. PURCHASE Or SAFE. Owing to the large amount of bunds which our state school funds hold and which are on file in this office I believe that a safe should be purchased which would be large enough to hold these securities and which is known to be absolutely fire proof, as I am inform' < by a safe expert th: *he safe which now aolds this $8,000,000 of bonds is not fire proof >.nd with this valuable an. unt of bonds some protection should be made for their safe keeping. Owing to the constitutional amendment providing for the investment in school bonds we will have such an increase in number of bonds that it will require more space than we have at the present time and our safe being filled it will be necessary that some provision be made for the storage of bonds purchased during the next two years. REPAIR OF VAULT. BI would '■all your attention to the bad repair which ; V.e state urer's \: H is in at the present * : "ne. I believe that for the pro - on of the records which are on ihe in the treasurer's office res shoul" 'je furnished for such vault. BOND OF STATE TREASURER. Under the present law in relating to furnishing bond the state treasurer has *-:en compelled to furbish a bond in the amount of $1,000,000 and in order to furnish this bond he must either L^ve it in a company which has capital ~nd surplus in the amount of $1,000,000 or he may furnish a joint bouJ in several smaller com.^i.nies which have ck. .tal stock to exceed this amount, and as surety companies who place be is refuse to sign a j^int bond and so few companies doing business .n the state have j capital stock sufficient to write the bond, I > -aid recommend that a law be passed allowing any surety company doing business in this state to write a portion of the bond in a stated anic-'U so that the aggregate amount given by several bonding companies would equal the amount as required for the bond. BONDS FOR DEPOSITORY BANKS. il fould recommend that a law be passed so banks which become db|K)«itories for state funds may file with some designated state r securities for such deposit in lieu of surety bond as the law res ."*i the present time, or that it be optional with the depository

RKPORT OF THE 6 bank as to the security furnished, whether it be a personal or surety bond or securities for such deposit. STATE INSTITUTION CASH FIND. I The cash funds of the various institutions as handled at the p • e are very unsatisfactory to this department as well as to the board > have charge of the various institutions, and I would suggest that cash derived from all sources be paid to the state treasurer and l the law be amended so that an institution can withdraw funds emergency purposes by giving a check on the state treasurer drawn the cash fund belonging to that institution, signed by the steward countersigned by the superintendent ; that each check state for it purpose this money was paid; that no money be drawn by an in - ution until a permit has been given for the purchase of such des as they desire to purchase, and that the amount as drawn per nth shall be limited according to the size of the state institution. UNIVERSITY LEVY. The last legislature made appropriation which provided that the proceeds from a one mill levy be used for state university current expenses and the supreme court has held that the auditor is compelled to draw warrants whether or not there are any proceeds on hand in this fund in payment of same. It has raised a question in this de - partment as to when and where this amount should begin and cease, as under the present system the state university has this fund over - drawn at the end of this biennium in the amount of $11 7, MO. 90. I believe it would be to the best interests of the state if the regents o' tbe university ask for a stipulated amount so that this department will know when the account has been drawn in amount of appropriation. SUPPLY BOARD. As a member of the Purchase and Supply Board of the various •tate institutions I am led to suggest a remedy which I feel would be beneficial to the state financially. That is that a warehouse be pro - vided at some central shipping point: that the Board of Purchase and Supplies employ a good competent storekeeper who would take charge of this storeroom and aid the supply board in buying supplies for all state institution needs; that an appropriation be made in one lump sum for the purpose of buying such goods and supplies, and that an institution be required to make requisition upon this storekeeper for whatever goods the institution's needs demand. I believe by this method goods could be purchased in car lots and a vast saving could be made over the present system of buying for each institution sepa - rately, as the law now requires to be done. PRINTING BOARD. As a member of the State Printing Board and having had experi - ence in relation to the necessity of employing a printing expert in or-

STATE TREASURER 7 der to buy b:>< lonery and other supplies which come under this depa tmtnt, I Iflieve that it would be advisable to establish a store - room in the capitol under this secretary's management; that supplies be pui chased by him through the direction of the Printing Board under contract as the usual method; that the various offices and institutions be required to buy all books, blanks and stationery through this de - partment and that he give out these supplies upon requisitions made by the various departments. EQUALIZATION" AND ASSESSMENT. IF:om the standpoint of a state officer the Board of Equalization Assessment is one of the most undesirable and responsible boards which I am a member. In making recommendations \ipon this stion I will in a short space attempt to outline a proposition that past experience has brought forth as a plan to overcome in: ition which at the present time different parts of the state are iplaining of. I feel that the people of the state do not understand tba ditions that arise in making a fair and just assessment of railroads and a fair and just equalization of other property in thi - realize that it is impossible for this board to know accura.ely the values of different property in different parts of the state and that by seeing the values upon paper and comparing them with other counties is the only way we have of knowing whether one county is 1 • proportion of state taxes with the other counties. In onl - .itne this difficulty which arises before this board annually, and more particularly every four years when the readjustment <>f I values is made, 1 would suggest that each counts ,ilues of their property as they deem best to meet the conditions in then - part of the state which do not arise in other parts and in ord' accomplish this purpose I believe that if the public service corpora - tions in the state were required to pay the expenses as created by the state and each county pay the expenses as created by that county upon the assessed value of all property within the county except I corporations the difficulty in equalization between the various coun - ties in the state would be overcome. The following summaries and statements are respectfully sub- L. G. BRIAN",
